column1: question
What type of design was used?
column5: block design | event related design | mixed

column1: Clearly describe each condition and the stimuli used.
column3: Be sure to completely describe baseline (for example, blank white/black screen, presence of fixation cross, or any other text), especially for resting ­state studies. When possible provide images or screen snapshots of the stimuli
column24: RELEVANT TO DESCRIBE THE INCLUDED STUDIES

column1: Number of trials/blocks per run per condition
column3: Specify per run, and if differing by subject, specify summary statistics (mean, range and/or standard deviation) of such counts

column1: What was the duration of one block?
What was the duration of one trial?
Provide the timing structure of the events in the task.
column3: Whether a random / jittered pattern or a regular arrangement; any jittering of block onsets.

column1: What was the intertrial interval range?
What was the intertrial interval distribution?
How many runs were used?
What was the duration of each imaging run?
What was the software used for stimuli presentation?
What was the software version used for stimuli presentation?
What operating system was used to present the stimuli?
Specify the URL of the experiment code.
Specify the instructions given to subjects for each condition
column3: Ideally copy the exact text. For resting ­state, be sure to indicate eyes­ closed, eyes­ open, any fixation. Describe if the subjects received any rewards during the task.

column1: Specifics of stimuli used in each run.
column3: For example, the unique number of stimuli used, and whether/how stimuli were repeated over trials or conditions

column1: Was the block or event ordering deterministic or randomized?
Describe how and the criteria used to constrain the orders/timings
Order in which tasks / runs are conducted
Was the order of the stimuli counterbalanced (across runs, across participants)?
How were responses collected?
column5: motor response (button boxes) |  motor response (other) |  other

column1: URL of stimuli database
Calibration procedure
column3: Including software (type, version and operating system) and hardware used, should also be described. Where relevant, the rationale for selecting a specific parameter (for example, contrast, harmonic content) should be indicated. If features were determined individually for each participant, the criteria and the psychophysical method used should be detailed.

column1: What sensory modality were used?
Visual stimuli: Specify the presentation hardware
column5: back projection | in­ room display | goggles

column1: Visual stimuli: Stimuli apparent size
column2: degrees of visual angle | cm | pixels

column1: Visual stimuli: Viewing distance
Visual stimuli: Clarity
Visual stimuli: Color
Visual stimuli: Site of the stimulation
Visual stimuli: Position in the visual field
Visual stimuli: Display device and method of projection
column3: - refresh rate  - response time of the monitors.

column1: Visual stimuli: Note if differences in intensity or contrast between different stimulus conditions
Audio stimuli: Stimulus properties
column3: For example, frequency content, duration, onset/offset envelope...

column1: Audio stimuli: Intensity
column3: for example, relative to the subject’s individual hearing threshold, or as Sound Pressure Level [dB SPL]

column1: Audio stimuli: Ear of stimulation
Audio stimuli: Type, manufacturer and model of the delivery device
column3: for example, ear inserts, panel speakers, etc.

column1: Audio stimuli: Further, the presence of contralateral ear masking stimulation, and its intensity, should be noted.
Tactile stimuli: Stimulus type
Tactile stimuli: Stimulus characteristics
Tactile stimuli: Location on the body with reference to anatomical landmarks
column3: location on the body with reference to anatomical landmarks, and strength (ideally with respect to some sensory or motor threshold) should be reported. The distance between the site of peripheral stimulation and brain, and skin temperature are also important as they will affect response latency independent of the experimental manipulation.

column1: Tactile stimuli: Was was the intensity of the stimulus?
column3: Ideally with respect to some sensory or motor threshold.

column1: Olfactory stimuli: Describe in detail any olfactory stimulation used.
Describe in detail any other stimulation not involving auditory, visual or somatosensory stimuli
Enumerate the conditions and fully describe and reference each.
column3: Consider using a shorthand name, for example, AUDSTIM, VISSTIM, to refer to each condition. Naming should reflect the distinction between instruction periods and actual stimuli.

column1: Was there any practice session?
Were feedbacks provided to the participant?
How were participants' errors handled?
What variables were recorded?
column24: IMPORTANT TO DESCRIBE STUDIES OR FOR INCLUSION CRITERIA

column1: Summaries of behavior sufficient to establish that subjects were performing the task as expected.
column3: For example, correct response rates and/or response times, summarized over subjects (for example, mean, range and/or standard deviation)
